modules.description: This module provides functions to convert interface identifiers to and from string, integer, and 32-bit integer representations. It operates on a single abstract data type `t`, representing IPv6 multicast interface indices. Concrete use cases include parsing interface indices from configuration strings and converting them to numeric types for system calls or network operations.

This module defines and manipulates socket address types for IPv6 multicast, supporting Unix domain paths, IPv4 and IPv6 addresses with associated ports and metadata. It provides conversions to and from `Unix.sockaddr` and binary representations using `Cstruct.t`. Concrete use cases include constructing multicast socket addresses for network communication and serializing them for transmission or storage.

This module configures socket options for IPv4 and IPv6 multicast communication. It provides direct access to multicast socket settings such as interface selection, time-to-live, loopback control, and group membership management. Use cases include setting up multicast listeners, controlling packet forwarding, and managing multicast group subscriptions in network applications.

This module directly manages IPv6 multicast socket creation and configuration, supporting operations like binding to interfaces, joining multicast groups, and sending/receiving multicast traffic. It works with domain types such as Unix, Inet, and Inet6, and socket types including stream, dgram, raw, and seqpacket. Concrete use cases include implementing multicast communication in network services, such as real-time data distribution or service discovery protocols.

This module enables IPv6 multicast communication through socket operations like binding, connecting, and sending or receiving byte buffers and Cstruct.t values, with support for control flags. It provides core functions for handling multicast data transmission and integrates submodules for interface index conversion, socket address manipulation, socket option configuration, and socket management. You can build multicast group listeners, send datagrams across interfaces, and handle incoming packets with precise flag handling, while also constructing and serializing socket addresses or configuring multicast settings like TTL and loopback. Direct API functions work alongside submodules to support use cases such as real-time data distribution and service discovery across Unix, Inet, and Inet6 domains.
